revision.text:
{{For|other people with the same name|Leslie Jones (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Leslie Jones | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Annette Jones | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1967|9|7}} | birth_place = [[Memphis]], [[Tennessee]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | religion = | medium = [[Stand-up comedy]], [[television]], [[film]] | genre = [[Observational humor]], [[blue comedy]], [[black comedy]], [[physical comedy]] | subject= [[African-American culture]], [[everyday life]], [[popular culture|pop culture]], [[current events]] | notable_work = ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' cast member, writer
''[[Ghostbusters (2016 film)|Ghostbusters]]'' (2016) | relatives = | module = | active = 1987–present | alma_mater = [[Colorado State University]] }} '''Annette Jones'''{{cite magazine|url=http://magazine.colostate.edu/issues/fall-2015/leslie-jones-found-her-funny-at-csu/|title=Leslie Jones Found Her Funny at CSU|first=Tony|last=Phifer|date=Fall 2015|work=The Magazine|publisher=Colorado State University|location=Fort Collins, Colorado|accessdate=July 31, 2017|archivedate=July 31, 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170731092134/http://magazine.colostate.edu/issues/fall-2015/leslie-jones-found-her-funny-at-csu/|deadurl=bot: unknown|quote=Jones (who went by Annette Jones at the time)...|df=mdy-all}} Additional July 31, 2017.{{cite magazine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SSgEAAAAMBAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q=annette&f=false|publisher=(Photo caption) ''[[Vibe (magazine)|Vibe]]'' (Vibe Media Group| page=112|date=June–July 2000| title=Intoxicating Humor | volume= 8|issue=5|issn=1070-4701|quote=Bacardi Comedy Champion Annette 'Leslie' Jones...}} (born September 7, 1967), better known as '''Leslie Jones''', is an American [[comedian]] and actress who is a cast member and writer on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. Jones has been a featured performer at the [[Just for Laughs]] festival in Montreal and the [[Aspen Comedy Festival]]. In 2010, her one-hour comedy special, ''Problem Child'', was broadcast on [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]]. Jones starred in ''[[Ghostbusters (2016 film)|Ghostbusters]]'' (2016) as Patty Tolan. In 2017 and 2018, Jones was nominated for an [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Comedy Series|Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Comedy Series]] for her work on ''Saturday Night Live''. == Early life == Annette Jones was born on September 7, 1967, in [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], Tennessee.{{cite web | url = http://www.biography.com/people/leslie-jones-071516|title=Leslie Jones Biography: Actress, Comedian (1967–)| publisher=[[Biography.com]] ([[FYI (TV channel)|FYI]] / [[A&E Networks]]) | accessdate= July 19, 2016| archivedate=July 19, 2016 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160719184104/http://www.biography.com/people/leslie-jones-071516 | deadurl=no}} Her father was in the [[United States Army]], and her family moved frequently.{{cite web|url=http://www.laughspin.com/2010/03/15/leslie-jones-just-wants-to-make-you-laugh/ |title=Leslie Jones: Just wants to make you laugh |publisher=LaughSpin |first=Noah |last=Gardenswartz |date=March 15, 2010 |accessdate=November 1, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141102051948/http://www.laughspin.com/2010/03/15/leslie-jones-just-wants-to-make-you-laugh/ |archivedate=November 2, 2014 }} Her family moved to [[Los Angeles]], when her father took a job at [[Stevie Wonder]]'s radio station, [[KJLH]], as an electronics engineer. Jones attended high school in [[Lynwood, California|Lynwood]], California, where she also played basketball; in May 2015, she said on ''[[Late Night with Seth Meyers]]'' that her father suggested that she play the sport because she is six feet tall.{{cite episode|title=Jane Fonda/Leslie Jones/Kay Cannon|series=[[Late Night with Seth Meyers]]|url=http://www.nbc.com/late-night-with-seth-meyers/blog/tuesday-jane-fonda-leslie-jones-kay-cannon|network=[[NBC]]|airdate=May 12, 2015|accessdate=August 4, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150528042945/http://www.nbc.com/late-night-with-seth-meyers/blog/tuesday-jane-fonda-leslie-jones-kay-cannon|archivedate=May 28, 2015|df=mdy-all}} Jones attended [[Chapman University]] on a basketball scholarship and transferred to [[Colorado State University]] when her coach left Chapman for Colorado State.{{Cite journal |last=Marantz |first=Andrew |authorlink= |date=January 4, 2016 |title=Ready for Prime Time |journal=[[The New Yorker]] |publisher=Condé Nast |pages=22–29 |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/01/04/ready-for-prime-time |accessdate=January 27, 2016 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/tv/leslie-jones-joins-saturday-night-live-cast-1.9526435 |title=Leslie Jones joins 'Saturday Night Live' cast |publisher=Newsday |date=October 20, 2014 |first=Verne |last=Gay |accessdate=October 21, 2014 }} She intended to become a lawyer,{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiego.com/articles/2011-11-03/leslie-jones-craft-comedy |title=Leslie Jones on the Craft of Comedy |publisher=SanDiego.com |date=November 3, 2011 |first=Gordon |last=Downs |accessdate=October 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140109052827/http://www.sandiego.com/articles/2011-11-03/leslie-jones-craft-comedy |archivedate=January 9, 2014 }} but changed her mind and changed her major a few times, including to business accounting and [[computer science]] and eventually ended up majoring in [[communications]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pollstar.com/news_article.aspx?ID=714652 |title=Leslie Jones: Comedian At Work |publisher=Pollstar.com |date=March 19, 2010 |accessdate=November 3, 2014|archivedate=July 31, 2017|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170731092358/https://www.pollstar.com/article/leslie-jones-comedian-at-work-15922|deadurl=no }} At Chapman, Jones became a radio [[DJ]]. She was unsure of what she wanted to do and contemplated the possibility of a career playing basketball overseas. She had a brother, Rodney Keith Jones (1971-2009).{{cite tweet| last=Jones |first=Leslie |user=lesdoggg |number=566285185952784384 |date= February 13, 2015 |title= Really missing my brother today.... |access-date=July 31, 2017 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20170731093023/https://twitter.com/lesdoggg/status/566285185952784384 |archive-date=July 31, 2017 |dead-url=no}} "quote=Rest in peace Rodney Keith." == Career == === Stand-up === Jones started to do stand-up comedy in college in 1987, when a friend signed her up for a "Funniest Person on Campus" contest. After she won the contest, Jones left school and moved to Los Angeles. She performed at regular clubs and worked at [[Roscoe's House of Chicken and Waffles]] and [[United Parcel Service|UPS]]{{cite web|url=http://justleslie.com/?page_id=16 |title=BIOGRAPHY |publisher=Justleslie.com |accessdate=November 3, 2014 }} to make ends meet. [[Mother Love]] and [[Dave Chappelle]] encouraged her to move to [[New York City]] to hone her craft for two years, where she appeared on [[BET]]'s ''[[ComicView]]'' before returning to Los Angeles. She performed at [[The Comedy Store]] in [[West Hollywood, California|West Hollywood]], but received unfavorable reviews. She opened up for [[Jamie Foxx]] and was booed by the audience. Feeling discouraged, Jones stopped performing for three years. In 2008, Jones was part of [[Katt Williams]]'s ''[[It's Pimpin' Pimpin']]'' tour.{{cite web|url=http://thecomicscomic.com/2010/03/02/leslie-jones-aka-big-les-may-be-a-problem-child-but-knows-when-to-take-katt-williams-advice/ |title=Leslie Jones, aka Big Les, may be a "Problem Child," but knows when to take Katt Williams’ advice |publisher=thecomicscomic.com |date=March 2, 2010 |first=Sean L. |last=McCarthy |accessdate=November 3, 2014 }} === ''Saturday Night Live'' === In December 2013, ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' held a casting call to add at least one African-American woman to the show, and Jones auditioned. Prior to being asked to audition, Jones had criticized the show, saying that the show, and especially cast member [[Kenan Thompson]], was "not funny".{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DhvKGF93WBk?t=63|title=Leslie Jones – Russell Simmons' A.D.D.|first=|last=Patricia Tone|date=October 27, 2013|publisher=|via=YouTube}} [[Sasheer Zamata]] was added as a featured player, while Jones and LaKendra Tookes were hired as writers.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/01/08/snl-lakendra-tookes-leslie-jones-writing-team_n_4563358.html |title='SNL' Adds Two Black Writers, LaKendra Tookes And Leslie Jones, After Hiring Black Cast Member (VIDEO) |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=January 8, 2014 |accessdate=October 21, 2014 }} Jones appeared during the Weekend Update segment of the May 3, 2014 episode hosted by [[Andrew Garfield]], where her jokes about her current dating problems and her potential effectiveness as a [[Slave breeding in the United States|breeding slave]] were met with controversy.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/05/05/leslie-jones-slave-sketch_n_5269479.html |title='SNL' Writer Leslie Jones Defends Controversial Slave Sketch (VIDEO) |publisher=''The Huffington Post'' |date=May 5, 2014 |accessdate=October 21, 2014 }} Jones appeared in the first and third episodes of the 40th season, hosted by [[Chris Pratt]] and [[Bill Hader]], respectively. On October 20, 2014, Jones was promoted to the cast as a featured player, and made her official debut on the October 25, 2014 episode hosted by [[Jim Carrey]]. She became, at the age of 47, the oldest person to join the show as a cast member (surpassing [[Michael McKean]] and [[George Coe]], who were 46 when they joined the show in, respectively, 1994 and 1975).{{cite web|title=Original 'SNL' Cast MemberGeorge Coe Dies|date=July 20, 2015|author=TMZ Staff|url=http://www.tmz.com/2015/07/20/george-coe-dies-archer-saturday-night-live-dead|publisher=[[TMZ]]}}{{cite web|url=http://splitsider.com/2013/07/saturday-nights-children-michael-mckean-1994-1995|title=Saturday Night's Children: Michael McKean (1994–1995) {{!}} Splitsider|work=[[The Awl|Splitsider]]|last=Wright|first=Megh|date=July 9, 2013|accessdate=December 18, 2014}} Jones' addition marks the first time in ''SNL'' history that the show's cast has included more than one African-American woman; in addition, the 40th season has the most African-American cast members to date.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2014/10/leslie-jones-saturday-night-live-new-cast-member-856104/ |title=Leslie Jones Named ‘Saturday Night Live’ Cast Member |publisher=Deadline |date=October 20, 2014 |first=Nellie |last=Andreeva |accessdate=October 21, 2014 }} Jones subsequently returned for [[Saturday Night Live (season 41)|Seasons 41]], [[Saturday Night Live (season 42)|42]], and [[Saturday Night Live (season 43)|43]]. In 2017 and 2018, Jones was nominated for an [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Comedy Series|Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Comedy Series]] for her work on ''SNL.'' === Film === In 2006, Jones appeared in [[Master P]]'s movie ''Repos''. In 2014, Jones appeared in [[Chris Rock]]'s directing debut, ''Top Five''; Rock has said a follow-up is in the works,{{cite news|last1=Chen|first1=Jonathan|title=A New Chris Rock Film is in The Works, Follow-up to Top Five|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2015/03/a-new-chris-rock-film-is-in-the-works.html|accessdate=September 12, 2016|work=Paste Magazine|date=March 19, 2015}} telling ''[[Complex Magazine]]'', "Some people really shine in ''Top Five''. You might want to see a little more Leslie Jones."{{cite news|last1=Frazier|first1=Tharpe|title=Interview: Chris Rock Talks His New Movie and Racist Fraternities: "The Girls Scare Me More Than the Guys"|url=http://www.complex.com/pop-culture/2015/03/chris-rock-interview|accessdate=September 12, 2016|work=Complex|date=March 19, 2015}} In 2015, Jones appeared in the [[Judd Apatow]] and [[Amy Schumer]] project, ''[[Trainwreck (film)|Trainwreck]]''; reportedly Apatow and Schumer wrote a part specifically for Jones after seeing her turn in ''Top Five''.{{cite news|last1=Jung|first1=E. Alex|title=Leslie Jones Is Awesome, So Obviously Her New Yorker Profile Is Too|url=http://www.vulture.com/2015/12/11-gems-from-leslie-joness-new-yorker-profile.html|accessdate=September 12, 2016| work=Vulture|date=December 28, 2015}} In 2016, she starred in the [[Reboot (fiction)|reboot]] ''[[Ghostbusters (2016 film)|Ghostbusters]]'' as Patty Tolan, alongside [[Melissa McCarthy]], [[Kristen Wiig]], and [[Kate McKinnon]].{{cite web|url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3329761/heres-whos-talks-ghostbusters/ |title= Meet Your All-Female ‘Ghostbusters’! |publisher=Bloody Disgusting |date=October 20, 2014 |first=Nellie |last=Andreeva |accessdate=October 21, 2014 }} === Olympics === During the [[2016 olympic games|2016 Olympic Games]] in [[Rio de Janeiro|Rio]], Jones drew attention on [[social media]] and in the press as a [[Team USA]] "superfan",{{cite news|last1=Dessem|first1=Matthew|title=Leslie Jones’ Olympics Tweets Are So Intense, NBC Invited Her to Rio|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2016/08/07/leslie_jones_tweeted_her_way_to_an_olympics_invitation.html|accessdate=August 31, 2016|work=Slate|date=August 7, 2016}} regularly live-tweeting events and posting videos of her reactions.{{cite news|last1=Liptak|first1=Andrew|title=Leslie Jones' Olympic live tweeting just got her invited to Rio|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/8/7/12397894/nbc-leslie-jones-rio-olympics-tweeting|accessdate=August 31, 2016|work=The Verge|date=August 7, 2016}} Enthusiasm for Jones's commentary grew, with articles appearing like ''[[The Huffington Post]]''{{'}}s "Watching Leslie Jones Watch The Olympics Is Better Than The Actual Olympics".{{cite news|last1=Delbyck|first1=Cole|title=Watching Leslie Jones Watch The Olympics Is Better Than Actual Olympics|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/leslie-jones-watching-olympics_us_57a63bd5e4b021fd9878cf80|accessdate=August 31, 2016|work=The Huffington Post|date=August 6, 2016}} Television producer [[Mike Shoemaker]], one of Jones's Twitter followers, posted on [[Twitter]] that his friend Jim Bell, [[NBC]]'s executive producer of the network's Olympics coverage, should add Jones to NBC's team of commentators covering the Games; Bell responded on Twitter the next day asking Jones to join NBC in Rio. She accepted and flew to Rio, covering swimming, track and field, gymnastics, and beach volleyball for NBC.{{cite news|last1=Lincoln|first1=Ross A.|title=Leslie Jones Accepts NBC Invite To Rio Olympics After Tweet-Storm Goes Viral – Update|url=http://deadline.com/2016/08/rio-olympics-leslie-jones-nbc-1201799880/|accessdate=August 31, 2016|date=August 8, 2016}} Jones reprised her duties at the [[2018 Winter Olympics]].http://ew.com/tv/2018/01/30/leslie-jones-2018-winter-olympics-nbc/ === Other projects === Jones and fellow comedian [[Adam DeVine]] appeared in a 2016 ad campaign for [[Allstate Insurance]], created by [[Leo Burnett Worldwide]].{{cite news |last=Lazare |first=Lewis |url= http://www.bizjournals.com/chicago/news/2016/05/12/allstate-turns-to-adam-devine-and-leslie-jones-for.html |title=Allstate turns to Adam DeVine and Leslie Jones for comedic effect in new brand ads |work=[[Chicago Business Journal]] |date=May 12, 2016 |accessdate=June 5, 2016}} Jones hosted the [[BET Awards]] on June 25, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/7808596/2017-bet-awards-leslie-jones-host|title=Leslie Jones to Host 2017 BET Awards|publisher=}} This marked her hosting debut. In 2018, Jones appeared in two advertisements for [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]]'s [[Amazon Echo|Echo Spot]].http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/amazons-super-bowl-ad-came-with-an-extra-spot-after-the-game/ === Sports fandom === Jones is a fan of the [[MLS]] team [[Seattle Sounders FC]].https://www.foxsports.com/soccer/story/watch-seattle-seahawks-reaction-sounders-mls-cup-win-121116 == Influences == Jones has cited as her comedic influences [[Eddie Murphy]], [[Richard Pryor]], [[Carol Burnett]]{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=63HOqonso24?t=166|title=Leslie Jones Video Blog: Female Comics|first=|last=LeslieJonesVideoBlog|date=December 9, 2011|publisher=|via=YouTube}}, [[Lucille Ball]], [[John Ritter]], and [[Whoopi Goldberg]]. == Online attacks == Following the release of ''[[Ghostbusters (2016 film)|Ghostbusters]]'', Jones became the target of numerous accounts on social networking site [[Twitter]] making racially charged attacks. [[Twitter]] responded by taking action against several users, resulting in the permanent [[Twitter suspensions| Twitter suspension]] of user and [[Breitbart News|Breitbart]] editor [[Milo Yiannopoulos]], who had described her as "barely literate".{{cite news|last=Roy|first=Jessica|title=Twitter bans Breitbart's Milo Yiannopoulos for harassment|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-et-mn-twitter-milo-yiannopoulos-20160719-snap-story.html|accessdate=July 20, 2016|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=July 19, 2016}} After continuing to receive racial comments towards her, Jones announced that she would be leaving Twitter on July 18, 2016.{{cite news|last=Fisher|first=Lucina|title='Ghostbusters' Star Leslie Jones Quits Twitter After Online Harassment|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/ghostbusters-star-leslie-jones-quits-twitter-online-harassment/story?id=40698459|accessdate=July 20, 2016|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=July 20, 2016}} Jones appeared later in the week on ''[[Late Night with Seth Meyers]]'', in which she described the ordeal and her meeting with Twitter CEO [[Jack Dorsey]]. Responding to Yiannopoulos's claim that he was targeted for being a "gay conservative", Jones stated, "Free speech and hate speech [are] two different things".{{cite web|url=http://www.nbc.com/late-night-with-seth-meyers/video/leslie-jones-on-her-twitter-trolls/3072412|title=Leslie Jones on Her Twitter Trolls|date=July 22, 2016|publisher=[[NBC]]}} Nearly a month later, Jones was again the subject of numerous online attacks. Her personal website was hacked, with its contents being replaced by photos of her driver's license and passport.{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/leslie-jones-website-hacked-article-1.2764043?cid=bitly|title=Leslie Jones’ website hacked, exposing nude photos, personal info|publisher=}} The site was also made to display alleged nude photographs of Jones, as well as a video tribute to [[killing of Harambe|Harambe]], the Cincinnati Zoo gorilla killed in May 2016 (a reference to the racially charged gorilla remarks directed at Jones in the earlier attack). Jones' team took the website down shortly after it was hacked.{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/08/24/the-hacking-of-leslie-jones-exposes-misogynoir-at-its-worst.html|title=The Hacking of Leslie Jones Exposes Misogynoir at Its Worst|first=Amy|last=Zimmerman|date=August 25, 2016|publisher=}} Both incidents resulted in large outpourings of celebrity and fan support, via the hashtag "#LoveForLeslieJ", which trended on both Twitter and Instagram.{{cite web|url=http://www.vibe.com/2016/07/love-for-leslie-j-twitter-trends/|title=#LoveForLeslieJ Trends On Twitter After "Ghostbusters" Backlash|date=July 20, 2016|publisher=}} [[Paul Feig]],{{cite news|last1=Ledbetter|first1=Carly|title=Celebrities Rally Around Leslie Jones After Vicious Internet Hack|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/celebrities-rally-around-leslie-jones-after-vicious-internet-hack_us_57bdee81e4b04193420ce577|accessdate=August 31, 2016|work=The Huffington Post|date=August 24, 2016}} [[Gabourey Sidibe]], [[Ellen DeGeneres]], [[Sara Benincasa]], [[Ava DuVernay]], [[Hillary Clinton]], [[Corey Taylor]],{{cite news|last1=Yee|first1=Lawrence|title=Leslie Jones Hack: Celebrities Come to Her Defense|url=https://variety.com/2016/digital/news/leslie-jones-hack-reaction-twitter-katy-perry-paul-feig-1201843942/|accessdate=August 31, 2016|work=Variety|date=August 24, 2016}} [[Katy Perry]], [[Octavia Spencer]], [[Anna Kendrick]], [[Lena Dunham]]{{cite news|last1=O'Malley|first1=Katie|title=Celebrities Come Out To Support Leslie Jones Following Hacking|url=http://www.elleuk.com/life-and-culture/elle-voices/news/a31646/celebrities-come-out-to-support-leslie-jones-following-hacking/|accessdate=August 31, 2016|work=Elle|date=August 25, 2016}} and [[Loni Love]] expressed solidarity with Jones. Jones responded to the hacks on the October 22, 2016, episode of ''Saturday Night Live''.{{cite news|last=Golgowski|first=Nina|title=Leslie Jones Shoots Down Trolls In Epic ‘Saturday Night Live’ Segment|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/leslie-jones-trolls-snl_us_580cedb4e4b02444efa3edc4|accessdate=October 25, 2016|work=[[Huffington Post]]|date=October 23, 2016}} == Filmography == === Film === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Film title ! Role ! class="unsortable" |Notes |- |align="center"|1999 |''[[For Love of the Game (film)|For Love of the Game]]'' |(uncredited) |https://web.archive.org/web/20090301183710/http://www.myspace.com:80/lesliejonescomedy |- |align="center"|2003 |''[[National Security (2003 film)|National Security]]'' |Britney | |- |align="center"|2006 |''Repos'' |Lay La |Credited as Annette Jones |- |align="center"|2007 |''[[Gangsta Rap: The Glockumentary]]'' |Mamma Du Rag |Credited as Annette "Leslie" Jones |- |align="center"|2008 |''Internet Dating'' |Too Sweett Jones | |- |rowspan="3" align="center"|2010 |''Something Like a Business '' |Vanity | |- |''[[Lottery Ticket (2010 film)|Lottery Ticket]]'' |Tasha | |- |''The Company We Keep'' |Beverly Blue | |- |rowspan="2" align="center"|2012 |''House Arrest'' |Boss Lady | |- |''Christmas in Compton'' (aka ''One Bad Christmas'') |Tiny | |- |rowspan="2" align="center"|2014 |''[[Top Five]]'' |Lisa | |- |''Kony Montana'' (aka ''[[Michael Blackson]] is Kony Montana'') |Fufu | |- |rowspan="2" align="center"|2015 |''We Are Family'' |Leslie (The Driver) | |- |''[[Trainwreck (film)|Trainwreck]]'' |Angry Subway Patron | |- |rowspan="3" align="center"|2016 | ''[[Ghostbusters (2016 film)|Ghostbusters]]'' | Patty Tolan | |- | ''[[Sing (2016 American film)|Sing]]'' | Meena's mother | Voice |- |''[[Masterminds (2016 film)|Masterminds]]'' | FBI Special Agent Scanlon | |- |align="center"|2019 |''[[The Angry Birds Movie 2]]'' | Gale |Voice |} === Television === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class="unsortable" |Notes |- |align="center"|1996 |''[[In The House (TV series)|In The House]]'' |Female Basketball Player (uncredited) |Episode: "Hoop Screams". |- |align="center"|1997 |''[[Coach (TV series)|Coach]]'' |(uncredited) |Episode: "It's A Swamp Thing". |- |align="center"|2001–02 |''The Way We Do It'' |Various | |- |align="center"|2004 |''[[Girlfriends (U.S. TV series)|Girlfriends]]'' |Mabel |Episode: "Love, Peace and Hair Grease". Credited as Leslie. |- |rowspan="2" align="center"|2007 |''[[Mind of Mencia]]'' |Nurse Brownsugar/Bodyguard |2 episodes |- |''[[American Body Shop]]'' |Roshanda Washington |Episode: "Fluids" |- |rowspan="2" align="center"|2010 |''[[Chelsea Lately]]'' |Herself (roundtable panelist) |Episode: "Crispin Glover" |- |''Problem Child: Leslie Jones'' (aka ''Big Les: Problem Child'') |Herself |Showtime stand-up comedy special. |- |align="center"|2012 |''[[Daddy Knows Best]]'' |Angry Woman |Episode: "Taser" |- |rowspan="3" align="center"|2013 |''[[Sullivan & Son]]'' |Bobbie |Episode: "Acceptance" |- |''[[See Dad Run]]'' |Security Guard |Episode: "See Dad Be Normal...ish" |- |''[[The League (TV series)|The League]]'' |Stand Up Student |Episode: "The Bringer Show" |- |align="center"|2014–present |''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' |Various |Cast member and writer
Nominated – [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Comedy Series]] (2017, 2018)
Nominated – [[Writers Guild of America Award]] for Outstanding Writing in a Comedy/Variety Series (2015) |- |align="center"|2014 |''[[Workaholics]]'' |Lynette |Episode: "The One Where the Guys Play Basketball and Do the Friends Title Thing" |- |align="center"|2015 |''[[The Awesomes]]'' |Silent But Deadly |Voice, Episode: "The Final Showdown" |- |align="center"|2016 |''[[The Blacklist (TV series)|The Blacklist]]'' |Citizen |Episode: "Lady Ambrosia" |- |align="center"|2018 |''[[Kevin (Probably) Saves the World]]'' |Cindy |Episode: "The Right Thing"https://www.tvinsider.com/667406/jason-ritter-kevin-probably-saves-the-world/ |} == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{IMDb name|nm0428656|label=Leslie Jones}} * {{twitter|Lesdoggg}} {{SNLCurrentCast}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jones, Leslie}} [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century American comedians]] [[Category:21st-century American comedians]] [[Category:20th-century American actresses]] [[Category:21st-century American actresses]] [[Category:Actresses from Los Angeles]] [[Category:Actresses from Memphis, Tennessee]] [[Category:African-American actresses]] [[Category:African-American stand-up comedians]] [[Category:American stand-up comedians]] [[Category:African-American writers]] [[Category:American writers]] [[Category:American film actresses]] [[Category:American television actresses]] [[Category:American women comedians]] [[Category:Chapman University alumni]] [[Category:Colorado State Rams women's basketball players]] [[Category:Colorado State University alumni]] [[Category:People from Lynwood, California]] [[Category:Writers from California]] [[Category:Writers from Tennessee]] [[Category:Military brats]] [[Category:American sketch comedians]] [[Category:Activists from California]] [[Category:Comedians from California]]
